text: BACKGROUND : <extra_id_0> IL-5 <extra_id_2> Protein <extra_id_1> controls development of eosinophilia and has been shown to be involved in the pathogenesis of allergic diseases .
In both atopic and nonatopic asthma , elevated <extra_id_0> IL-5 <extra_id_2> Protein <extra_id_1> has been detected in peripheral blood and the airways .
<extra_id_0> IL-5 <extra_id_2> Protein <extra_id_1> is produced mainly by activated T cells , and its expression is regulated at the transcriptional level .

text: OBJECTIVE : This study focuses on the functional analysis of the human <extra_id_0> IL-5 <extra_id_2> Protein <extra_id_1> ( <extra_id_0> hIL-5 <extra_id_2> Protein <extra_id_1> ) promoter and characterization of cis - regulatory elements and transcription factors involved in the suppression of <extra_id_0> IL-5 <extra_id_2> Protein <extra_id_1> transcription in T cells .

text: METHODS : Methods used in this study include DNase I footprint assays , electrophoretic mobility shift assays , and functional analysis by mammalian cell transfection involving deletion analysis and site - directed mutagenesis .
RESULTS : We identified 5 protein binding regions ( BRs ) located within the proximal <extra_id_0> hIL-5 <extra_id_2> Protein <extra_id_1> promoter .
Functional analysis indicates that the BRs are involved in control of <extra_id_0> hIL-5 <extra_id_2> Protein <extra_id_1> promoter activity .
Two of these regions , BR3 and BR4 located at positions -102 to -73 , have not previously been described as regulators of <extra_id_0> IL-5 <extra_id_2> Protein <extra_id_1> expression in T cells .

text: We show that the BR3 sequence contains a novel negative regulatory element located at positions -90 to -79 of the <extra_id_0> hIL-5 <extra_id_2> Protein <extra_id_1> promoter , which binds <extra_id_0> Oct1 <extra_id_2> Protein <extra_id_1> , octamer-like , and <extra_id_0> YY1 <extra_id_2> Protein <extra_id_1> nuclear factors .

text: Substitution mutations , which abolished binding of these proteins to the BR3 sequence , significantly increased <extra_id_0> hIL-5 <extra_id_2> Protein <extra_id_1> promoter activity in activated T cells .

CONCLUSION : We suggest that <extra_id_0> Oct1 <extra_id_2> Protein <extra_id_1> , <extra_id_0> YY1 <extra_id_2> Protein <extra_id_1> , and octamer-like factors binding to the -90 / -79 sequence within the proximal <extra_id_0> IL-5 <extra_id_2> Protein <extra_id_1> promoter are involved in suppression of <extra_id_0> IL-5 <extra_id_2> Protein <extra_id_1> transcription in T cells .
